position.marginalia_text: Catalogus illustrium virorum in Romana Historia. Ex Aurelio Victore seriatim transcriptus. (Licet idem ille liber aliis attributus, praesertim Cornelio Nepoti, et Plino Caecilio.) Meorum unus mnemonicorum elenchorum. Proca, rex Albanoru[m]. Romulus, Romanoru[m] rex I. Numa Pompilius, Rom[anorum] rex 2. Tullus Hostilius, Rom[anorum] rex 3.

Horatii, et Curiatii. Metius Fufetius. Ancus Marcius, Rom[anorum] rex 4. Tarquinius Priscus, Rom[anorum] rex V. Servius Tullius, rex 6. Tullia. Tarquinius Superbus, Rom[anorum] rex 7. Tarquinius Collatinus, et Lucretia uxor. Junius Brutus, Romanoru[m] consul I. Horatius Cocles. Mutius Scaevola. Claelia virgo. Fabii trecentisex. L[ucius] Valerius Poblicola. Aulus Posthumius dictator. Quinctius Cincinnatus, dictator. Menenius Agrippa Lanatus. Marcius Coriolanus. Licinius Stolo. Virginius Centurio. Aesculapius Romam advectus; anguis specie. M[arcus] Furius Camillus. Manlius Capitolinus. Cornelius Cossus. Decius pater. Decius filius. Valerius Corvinus. Spurius Posthumius. Papyrius Cursor. Fabius Rullianus. Curius Dentatus. Appius Claudius Caecus. Pyrrhus, rex Epeirotarum. Fabricius. Decius Mus. Appius Claudius Caudex. [Gaius] Duilius. Atilius Calatinus. Atilius Regulus. Lutatius Catulus. Annibal, Carthaginensis dux. Q[uintus] Fabius Maximus. Cunctator. P. Scipio Nasica. M. Claudius Marcellus. Livia Claudia, virgo Vestalis. Porcius Cato Censorius. Claudius Nero; et Asdrubal frater Annibalis. P[ublius] Cornelius Scipio Africanus. M. Livius Salinator. Quinctius Flaminius. alias Flaminius. Fulvius Nobilior. L[ucius] Scipio Asiaticus. Antiochus, rex Syriae. [Gnaeus] Manlius Vulso. Paulus Aemylius Macedonicus. Tiberius Sempronius Gracchus. P[ublius] Scipio Aemilianus. [Gaius] Hostilius Mancinus. L[ucius] Mummius Achaicus. Q[uintus] Caecilius Metellus Macedonicus. Q[uintus] Caecilius Metellus Numidicus. Q[uintus] Metellus Pius. Tiberius Gracchus. Caius Gracchus. M[arcus] Livius Drusus. Marius pater. Marius filius. Cornelius Cinna. Flavius Fimbria. Viriatus Lusitanus.

M[arcus] Aemilius Scaurus. L[ucius] Appulcius Saturnius. L[ucius] Licinius Lucullus. L[ucius] Cornelius Sulla. Mithradates, rex Ponti. [Gnaeus] Pompeius Magnus. Atque hi illustrium Romanoru[m] praestantissimi. nisi quod in antiquo Additamento, hi etiam celebrantur illustres viri. Julius Caesar. Octavianus Caesar. Cato Praetorius. M[arcus] Tullius Cicero. Marcus Brutus. [Gaius] Cassius Longinus. Sextus Pompeius. Marcus Antonius. Cleopatra regina. In excellentissima Romanae Reip[ublicae] historia, ecce illustrium iam tum virorum selectissimi: praesertim suorum omnium fortissimi, atque prudentissimi. Nec ullus fere mnemonicus elenchus, altiori dignus impressione. Tanti ubique momenti, ista praeclara nomina. In quibus, quaedam totius Romanae historiae ars memorativa conspicue repraesentatur.

marginalia.translation: A catalogue of famous men in Roman history, copied sequentially from Aurelius Victor. (Although the very same book has been attributed to others, especially Cornelius Nepos and Pliny the Younger.) This is one of my lists for memory. Procas, king of the people of Alba Longa. Romulus, the first king of the Romans. Numa Pompilius, the second king of the Romans. Tullus Hostilius, the third king of the Romans. The [three] Horatii, and [three] Curiatii. Metius Fufetius. Ancus Marcius, the fourth king of the Romans. Tarquinius Priscus, the fifth king of the Romans. Servius Tullius, the sixth king of the Romans. Tullia. Tarquinius Superbus, the seventh king of the Romans. Tarquinius Collatinus, and his wife Lucretia. Junius Brutus, the first consul of the Romans. Horatius Cocles. Mutius Scaevola. The virgin Claelia. The 306 Fabii. Lucius Valerius Poblicola. The dictator Aulus Postumius. The dictator Quinctius Cincinnatus. Menenius Agrippa Lanatus. Marcius Coriolanus. Licinius Stolo. Virginius Centurio. Aesculapius brought to Rome, in the guise of a snake. M. Furius Camillus. Manlius Capitolinus. Cornelius Cossus. Decius, father. Decius, son. Valerius Corvinus. Spurius Postumius. Papyrius Cursor. Fabius Rullianus. Curius Dentatus. Appius Claudius Caecus. Pyrrhus, king of the people of Epirus. Fabricius. Decius Mus. Appius Claudius Caudex. Gaius Duilius. Atilius Calatinus. Atilius Regulus. Lutatius Catulus. Hannibal, the Carthagian leader. Quintus Fabius Maximus, Cunctator [‘the Delayer’]. Publius Scipio Nasica. Marcus Claudius Marcellus. Livia Claudia, Vestal virgin. Porcius Cato Censorius [Cato the Elder]. Claudius Nero; and Hasdrubal, Hannibal’s brother. Publius Cornelius Scipio Africanus. Marcus Livius Salinator. Quinctius Flaminius, also called Flaminius. Fulvius Nobilior. Lucius Scipio Asiaticus. Antiochus, king of Syria. Gnaeus Manlius Vulso. Paulus Aemilius Macedonicus. Tiberius Sempronius Gracchus. Publius Scipio Aemilianus. Gaius Hostilius Mancinus. Lucius Mummius Achaicus. Quintus Caecilius Metellus Macedonicus. Q. Caecilius Metellus Numidicus. Q. Metellus Pius. Tiberius Gracchus. Gaius Gracchus. Marcus Livius Drusus. Marius father. Marius son. Cornelius Cinna. Flavius Fimbria. Viriatus Lusitanus. Marcus Aemilius Scaurus. Lucius Appulcius Saturnius. Lucius Licinius Lucullus. Lucius Cornelius Sulla. Mithridates, king of Pontus. Pompey the Great. And these are the most outstanding of the famous Romans, except that in an ancient Supplement also the following famous men are praised: Julius Caesar; Octavian; Cato Praetorius; Marcus Tullius Cicero; Marcus Brutus; Gaius Cassius Longinus; Sextus Pompey; Mark Antony; Queen Cleopatra. These then are the most exquisite men, already famous at that time in the superior history of the Roman Republic, especially the bravest and most sagacious of all of them. Hardly any other memory list deserves a deeper imprint. So great and universal is the importance of those brilliant names. In a remarkable way they exhibit a sort of art of memory of the entire Roman history.
